metadata.title: Concrete Cylinder Volume Calculator
metadata.description: Calculate the volume and estimated material required for a cylindrical concrete element (core, column, test cylinder) from diameter and height inputs in inches. Outputs in cubic metres, cubic feet, cubic yards, mass (kg/lb), and estimated bag counts using standard densities.

introduction: This calculator computes the material quantities for a cylindrical concrete element (for example: test cylinder, column, pier) from diameter and height given in inches. Primary outputs include volume (m³, ft³, yd³), estimated mass (kg and lb) using a standard density, and approximate bag counts for commonly used bag sizes.

Default calculations assume normal-weight concrete at 2400 kg/m³ (approx. 150 lb/ft³). Use this tool for quick estimating; for design, bidding, or regulatory compliance verify site-specific densities, admixtures, and air content with laboratory data.
methodology: Volume is computed from the geometric cylinder formula: V = π × (d/2)² × h. Inputs are accepted in inches and converted to cubic metres for mass estimation. Conversion constants follow SI definitions (1 in = 0.0254 m, 1 ft³ = 0.0283168466 m³, 1 yd³ = 0.764554858 m³).

Mass uses a typical normal-weight concrete density of 2400 kg/m³. Concrete density varies with aggregate type, air entrainment, and mix design; where available use lab-confirmed unit weight for most accurate mass and bag-count estimates.

Bag-count estimates divide the calculated mass by the bag mass (50 kg for metric examples, 80 lb for common US bag size). Results are rounded to integer bag counts for ordering; always allow extra material for waste, over-excavation, and consolidation losses.

faqs.question: Can I enter dimensions in metric units?
faqs.answer: This version accepts diameter and height in inches. To use metric, convert metres to inches (1 m = 39.3701 in) or use a metric-specific tool. For reproducible results in SI, convert inputs to metres and compute using the cylinder formula with SI units; see NIST for SI unit definitions.

faqs.question: Why does the calculator use 2400 kg/m³ for density?
faqs.answer: 2400 kg/m³ is a common reference density for normal-weight concrete used for preliminary estimates. Actual unit weight depends on aggregate type, air content, moisture, and admixtures. For specification or laboratory reporting use the mix-specific unit weight from your mix design or testing laboratory.

faqs.question: How should I round bag estimates for ordering?
faqs.answer: Round bag estimates up to the next whole bag and add a contingency (commonly 5–10%) to account for waste, spillage, and finishing losses. Confirm bag yield from the bag manufacturer's technical data for precise ordering.

faqs.question: What measurement accuracy do I need for reliable estimates?
faqs.answer: Tape measures and calipers should be calibrated and read to the nearest practical subdivision (1/8 in or 1 mm) for small cylinders. Error in diameter is squared in the volume formula, so small diameter measurement errors have a larger effect than similar percentage errors in height.

faqs.question: Does reinforcement or voids change the results?
faqs.answer: Yes. Embedded reinforcement (rebar, rods) and internal voids reduce net concrete volume and increase mass of non-concrete components. Subtract the volume of known voids or reinforcement from the gross cylinder volume before computing concrete mass and bag counts.
